title: Intro to Mocking Unit Test Dependencies
abstract: In this talk, I cover unit test isolation and why it’s important, introduce mocking as a solution, show examples of mocking in popular programming languages, including a quick example of link-time interpositioning in C.
description:
Unit tests must exist in isolation. This is easier said than done. Your code may have many dependencies, depend on a long running process or on system calls. If we fail to address these issues, our tests will run slower, be less reliable and will make CI / CD a challenge. In order to test this code in isolation, we need to replace real objects and functions with our own implementations. This is called Mocking.

In this session, we will talk about the value of unit testing in isolation and strategies for isolating unit tests in Ruby and C by using both established frameworks and rolling our own mocks.

title: One DevOps platform for IT and Business - is that even possible?
abstract: In our talk, we’ll explain what is DevOps platform and why every software company needs it. We’ll also show some practical hints on how to sell it to management.
description:
Can you imagine how many people again and again install same DevOps tools and configure similar pipelines over and over again?
Let us introduce you to ADOP - the DevOps platform. It’s a framework which glues together suite of open-source DevOps tools and provides extremely quick way of mobilizing software development projects in a consistent way. It’s open-source and available on Github. The platform can be installed even on a laptop as well as on AWS, Azure etc. ADOP supports different programming languages or you can just run your Ops department on it. We truly believe it’s a must-have for any software company.
Having such platform in IT brings great value for any software business but sometimes it’s not that clear to management or Business people. So we’ll also show some do’s and don’ts on how to explain and sell it to them.
notes:

This is duo-presentation by two speakers - Arturs Kovalenko and Uldis Karlovs-Karlovskis.

We love DevOps and ADOP! Most of the time we spend on AWS, Docker, Jenkins, Groovy etc. to make ADOP better. When we’re tired running sprints, we go out and evangelize to make DevOps and ADOP more popular!

title: I have an idea, now what?
abstract: You have come up with THE next big idea that could change everything, but how do you get it out there? Come to learn the process of ideation through deployment. Code demos will be built in the JavaScript stack.
description: It can be so frustrating to come up with a great idea and not know how to get it out to the world. title: Think Offline-First
abstract: It is easy to forget, in a culture of always-on internet connections, that large portions of the world do not enjoy the same level of access as smartphone-wielding Westerners. Let us look at design guidelines and technologies for building offline-first products.
description:
The internet has become a necessity for some of us. It's become a preferable medium for some of us to communicate, share and receive information. As we move from place to place, we discover that connection speed vary from location to location. Different service provider work best at specific locations. Some places are just shut out and offline. Also not forgetting the cost of data and how we try to minimise data expense. 

In this talk, I teach Offline First. What it is, design guides, the benefits, technologies for building offline-first apps, and some products that has used it to gain broader reach and better serve their users.
notes:
No technical requirement. I'm the best on this subject because I'm a member of the offline-first community, where we're looking at patterns and practices for building applications for the developing world where inter is less affordable, less reliable and less available. I'm a contributor to Hoodie, an Open Source project for building offline-first product without worrying about backend. 
I also live in Nigeria, where internet connectivity is an issue, so I have first hand experience

title: Criptografía Open Source
abstract:
Se brindarán conceptos de Información y Privacidad, también de Criptografía, las ventajas de su uso y algoritmos criptográficos.
Luego se mostrará la instalación y el uso del Sistema criptográfico Veracrypt, detallando la creación y usos de contenedores cifrados.
description:

El planteo de la presente charla es ¿Qué tan segura está nuestra información? ¿Qué pasa si algún extraño pudiera acceder a nuestra información? ¿Nuestras fotografías privadas están protegidas, o corremos el riesgo de que un extraño o persona maliciosa invada nuestra privacidad?
El uso de herramientas de criptografía nos brindará la seguridad suficiente a la hora de transferir y/o guardar información.
En la presente charla se explicará el concepto de Criptografía Simétrica, Criptografía Asimétrica, se explicaran sus usos y se mostrará la instalación y el uso de la herramienta Veracrypt.

title: Empathetic Communication at Work
abstract: Communication is the one skill that will never be obsolete. Why, then, are so many of us intimidated by working on or beefing up our communication strategies? This interactive workshop tackles your communications fears and weaknesses head on with a full day focused how we speak and how we listen.
description:
Communication is the one skill that will never be obsolete. Why, then, are so many of us intimidated by working on or beefing up our communication strategies? We can all be great communicators, we just need to learn to approach it from a place of empathy. This interactive workshop tackles your communications fears and weaknesses head on with a full day focused on both sides of the conversation spectrum: speaking and listening. The main goal of this workshop is to learn how to approach every interaction from a place of empathy. Learners will leave this course with the tools to:
 
1. Understand the true purpose of listening
2. Shift listening into an action-based activity 
3. Identify biases and learn how to combat them
4. Fight fair and use those disagreements as gateways to collaboration
5. Craft responses that best helps their listeners understand and embrace their message
notes: This is appropriate for all audiences. Specifically, this workshop is for people that either want to improve upon their already great communication skills or work on weaknesses that they or their coworkers have identified as areas to improve.

title: Breaking the Binary World with Vue.js
abstract:
Vue.js is more consolidated than ever. It is the future of the MV* client side world and  is one of the most promising alternatives, fighting with industry giants like React and Angular 2.
I will show you the simplicity and power of this framework which combines the best parts of front end world.
description:
This talk exposes a binary situation in front-end world. Right now most people try to chose between React and Angular. Everybody knows that there are more choices but people prefer to pick between these two.

Thankfully the situation started to change and alternatives like Vue.js have an stronger role in front end apps.
I want to briefly introduce what is Vue.js and how it works.The idea is to review the core concepts of the framework but also see how you can scale progressively when you have complex requirements

I think would be great that Angular and React developers can see how to merge advantages and best parts of both frameworks to build a new one and break the polarization they have.

I am not an evangelist. I will not try to convince developers to use Vue, just show the features, uses cases and advantages. And also let know the audience that OSS projects could became great without Facebook or Google behind it.
notes:
According to Third Party Benchmark, Vue.js is one of the alternatives with better perfomance. Is also one of the mosts starred and forked project on GitHub. Its popularity and community has grown a lot last months. Besides that, there lot of people that could not learn it yet or would give it a chance. So I think is a great opportunity to make more popular.

I am an experienced full stack developer and programming mentor. I started "my career" as speaker last year participating in local conf and meetups. title: FindEarth - Hola Mundo!
abstract:
Quisiera presentar a la comunidad nuestro proyecto open source: Find Earth.
En conjunto con una de las ONG mas grandes de Argentina construimos una plataforma para ayudar a encontrar personas perdidas en todo el mundo.
description:
Find Earth es una plataforma open source, que tiene como objetivo facilitar el reporte de personas perdidas, agilizar la viralización de sus datos en redes sociales y lo más importante: ayudar a encontrarlas. 

Contamos con 3 piezas de software fundamentales: 

- Un dashboard que permite a los gobiernos u organizaciones concentrar la información de personas perdidas, obtener reportes, ser mas precisos en detalles de geolocalización y lo mas importante poder viralizar a las personas mediante redes sociales.
- Una aplicacion para celulares para que los ciudadanos se sumen a la iniciativa y puedan ser notificados cuando las personas se pierden cerca de sus barrios o vecindarios. De esta manera facilitamos las notificaciones y podemos recibir información valiosa en tiempo real.
- Un sitio web publico que permite listar personas desaparecidas, informar sobre las mismas y reportar nuevos casos.

Find Earth es un proyecto local que va a ser impulsado en primera instancia desde Argentina pero tiene la escalabilidad y arquitectura necesaria para poder desarrollarse a nivel gubernamental o empresarial en cualquier parte del mundo.

Fue desarrollada por un grupo de amigos en conjunto con la ONG mas importante de Argentina: Red Solidaria. El propósito de la charla es contar la experiencia de lo realizado, dar a conocer porque construimos esta plataforma, mostrar las herramientas y las tecnologías utilizadas (100% open source) y por ultimo concientizar a las personas que con un mīnimo aporte podemos ayudar a otras personas.
notes:
Mi nombre es Ignacio Anaya, soy uno de los creadores de la plataforma junto con Matias Tucci, Nicolas del Valle y Jonathan del Valle. Hace muchos años empezamos a hacer software para ayudar ONG's y para poder aportar un cambio en lo social desde el punto de vista del software.

Trabajamos varios proyectos sociales, como Frio Cero, Decinos Donde Votas y Precios Cuidados pero Find Earth es el proyecto mas grande que tenemos hasta ahora y el cual creemos que va a causar mayor impacto social, no solo en nuestra region sino en cualquier país donde se necesite.

La plataforma todavía no fue lanzada públicamente pero aquí están los links

Sitio Publico => https://find.earth/
GitHub => https://github.com/findearth

title: From PopcornTime to Butter, the fight for the right to make awesome software
abstract: We make Netflix tremble showing the world how easy it is to make a great video streaming experience with simple hacks and almost no money. obviously, that got a few people knocking on our door and got us from technical to legal hacks to be able to keep doing what we do: great Software that people ♥
description:
We live in a world of rich media, text, images and videos are ubiquitous to
our lives. Open-Source technology to distribute text and images to anyone is
common but we lack its video part. The solutions offered by the market are
usually expensive and require a massive installed infrastructure, de-facto
excluding most of the world's populous: emerging nations. Contrary to the
Text distribution revolution that built the Internet we all love, ttoday a
few companies hold patents locked technologies to position themselves as the
new 'media curators', Netflix, Hulu, HBO, YouTube, Facebook,… get to decide
and influence what is seen, when and where, destroying local content in
favor of the global one. Furthermore, the centralized logic of these
business models (and hence technologies) make their content unavailable in
poorly or disconnected areas, in essence, cultural inclusion is now bound to
internet access and we have deepened the digital breach.


We bring world-class highly distributed and decentralized technologies. We
empower emerging societies to enter the video distribution race side by side
to the biggest players. We make user-focused tools to build proven, solid
and useable Video On Demand (VOD) solutions that handle with extreme simplicity the whole
media workflow with close to zero pre-required technical knowledge and digital
infrastructure.

There are basically 3 classes of companies going to similar solutions,
commercial content broadcaster, user-content broadcaster and CDN providers.

The Commercial Content Broadcasters (CCB) will try to own all of the chain,
they buy content, build the user apps, distribute them, marked them build
the CDN and charge users. Some of them will even produce their own content
to feed into their solutions. In this realm our 'competitors' would be
Netflix, HBO, Amazon and Hulu.

Then the User-Content Broadcasters (UCB) will focus on building a content
distribution strategy for user content. They strip the content production
costs faced by the CCBs but need to provide infrastructure for a much higher
number of files. Here we're facing Facebook, Youtube and Vimeo.

Finally the CDN providers will only build the distribution technology and
sell that to 3rd parties interested in monetizing the content they own or
buy, their clients are usually ISPs, Telcos and Content groups, these are
our most direct competitors as we are a drop-in replacement for technologies
built by Akamai, Datco and Microsoft.

With Butter, we offer something these platforms don’t: 

- Through peer-to-peer, our infrastructure costs shrink to zero as demand grows
  reverting the traditional growth paradigm.

- Our user-owned technology makes the video content available in places with
  poor to no internet, we have working solutions working out of a $20 USD
  of-the-shelves wifi access point with a pendrive (great for small ISPs).

- With Butter you own your work, you own the user agreement, you own the
  rules, we have a zero trolling, censorship resistant, decentralized solution.

- Don't be excluded, all these platform's content can be integrated to
  Butter.

On top of everything, Butter offers an unmatched way to customize and
stylize the platform itself to truly reflect a vision one can have.

###What is your project doing? 

- Expanding/improving existing new technology/platform

We are bringing first world technology to developing countries and
culture-driven actors all around the world. We're building the "Android of
VOD", a tool for building strong, resilient and innovative applications, and
distributing video-content through direct connection with a server,
peer-to-peer sharing, or even simple network distribution without Internet
connectivity.

These use-cases of video streaming already exist separately but no software
managed to combine all these elements together, even less with a simple yet
powerful interface without direct code contribution required. Furthermore,
the use of Open Source licensing allows developers to directly get involved
with their platform and propose changes to Butter directly, on top of the
in-code modifications they might add.

The groundbreaking vision of Butter can empower youth, vulnerable
minorities, cooperatives and social actors but also companies or
organizations, by giving them a revolutionary way of gathering, sharing and
watching video-content.

### Our future
With ButterMaker, literally anyone will be able to build their stylized VOD
solutions, through a clean and user-friendly without any coding skills
required. The app will produce secure and updatable Butter applications on
any platform (currently Windows/OSX/Linux/iOS/Android). Our bleeding edge
Open Source technology stack is packaged and documented allowing the
tech-savvy to be-part of the deployment of world-class applications for
their communities.

ButterDAM will empower children, adolecents and youth to be their own media
curators, by selecting the video content and metadata pushed to users
through a simple interface connected to ButterMaker: Young media creators
will their content displayed in the spotlight.

Finally these local-owned, local-built Butter Apps, will move kids away from
globalized content to know and own their cultural heritage through
new-media.
notes:
This talk doesn't have much technical requirements, it's going to be mostly a flyhtrough what butter/popcorntime does and what is our vision for it.
I'm the best person to do that talk as the Butter Project Leader, speak native spanish and know a fair bit about Latin American politics.

title: Fallacies of Doom - Lessons learned from porting Doom 3 to Java
abstract:
While Java has grown enormously over the years, the fundamentals have stagnated.

The motivation for this talk and underlying project, was the following question: why is Java, with it's 20 years of age, and (at least)6 billion running JVM's not a major player in the video-game development universe?
description:
So everybody knows the Doom games, right? Every new installment brought brand new ideas, and groundbreaking graphics. But more importantly, they brought the source code of the prior installment to the eye of the public.

Naturally people have played and hacked the code to oblivion, as much as they played the games themselves. And I have the honor to be one of those people.

I (naively) endeavored to port the Doom 3 C++ code to our fantabulous Java. In doing so, I hoped to learn, among other things, more about 3D graphics.
...what I didn't expect though, was for djoom3(cool name huh!) to teach me more about Java!?

Aside from the basic game development intro, this talk focuses on the following:
- Some areas where Java should learn from it's nemesis, C++
- Other areas where the student(Java) becomes the master(C++)
- And some promises that were made, but never kept
notes:
All I require is some kind of projector or big monitor, which I assume will be provided.

This is an opinionated talk, but the content is all technically sound.
I guess what would make me the best person to speak about all of this, is the amount of time I spent on the djoom3 project, which is the main theme of the presentation.

abstract: Have you ever wanted to make your own game or animation? Processing is a great tool to help make compelling and professional artwork. I will explore some cool examples and features when using it as well as how to get set up.

title: Using Tor for Smart Home Security
abstract: The IoT is emerging as the third wave in the development of the Internet. We have a great danger with IoT because of the surveillance by an individual hacker or a state actor to exploit the very private information of individuals or companies. We can secure our “Smart Homes” by using TOR.
description:
Recent advances in information and communication technologies and embedded systems have given rise to a new disruptive technology: the Internet of Things (IoT). Internet of things (IoT) is expected to have a massive impact on consumer products, business and wider culture, but these are still early days.

The Internet of Things is a phenomenon where tiny machines have the ability to sense, respond, compute, and connect to the Internet, providing unprecedented access to control things and the environment around us. Along with advancement lies the problem going hand-to-hand.There have been many reports on how this things can be exploited to do various things in the Digital World.We need security because we don’t want others to control our home or disturb our privacy in our homes. TOR having been helping many people towards “Safe and Secure Browsing”. We can use “Tor” for securing our “Smart Home” so that we may not face the situations where we locked out by our home.

Security is extremely important for achieving this goal. As this worldwide network of interconnected objects can be exploited anywhere by anyone and anytime, it is necessary to enhance it with strong security foundations able to give birth to a world-changing paradigm.

The sense of fear that arises when using “Smart Homes” is addressed since, recently we have seen the “Dark Side” of Smart Homes and Internet of Things where people became aware of the risks of using more “IoT” which makes them more vulnerable and also effects their privacy.

title: Why we made an open-source project
abstract: In this talk learn the purposeful decision to open-source part of an existing product and why open-source is contributing to the overall strength and success of the product. We'll also go over ways to engage communities, some of struggles along the way, and metrics to help guide decision-making.
description: Singer was born out of experience writing Python script integrations that would break, lose data, and just waste time. Making Singer open-source was a purposeful move by the company meant to strengthen the community of integrations and make moving data easier. In this talk learn how the team created the product along with successes and failures along the way.

title: Ingenieria de software como alternativa para inmigrantes en latino america.
abstract: En los últimos 10 anos, Latino América a presentado una ola migratoria masiva;   solo en Argentina existen 5000 puestos en el area de tecnología no ocupados, cómo podemos usar todo esto a nuestro favor?
description:
En los últimos años Venezuela, Colombia y México presentan grandes indices de fuga de talento, países como Argentina, Estados Unidos y Chile tienen a ser destinos los jovenes debido las facilidades para conseguir una visa de trabajo gracias a convenios como el Mercosur. Sin embargo, insertarse en una sociedad nueva no es fácil, en el caso de Venezuela, la mayoría de los emigrantes son profesionales en areas como Medicina, Derecho e Ingenieria, por su parte Colombia y Mexico buscan destinos donde la educación no sea tan costosa para poder estudiar una carrera profesional, las realidades son varias.

En este caso puntual, me enfoco de la realidad de Argentina; actualmente según cifras de la Nación* existen aproximadamente 5000 puestos de trabajo que no están siendo ocupados en el area de informática (programación, administración de sistemas entre otros), por su parte, la desocupación en áreas como Educación, Medicina y Derecho es alarmante, actualmente las cifras de desempleo abarcar alrededor de 15%. Todo esto lleva a la interrogante, cómo podemos educar a nuestra sociedad en materia de ciencias de la computación para mejorar la calidad de vida y contribuir a la inserción de los profesionales a la sociedad?

El enfoque se encuentra en:
1- Soportar la diversidad de genero.
2- Presentar aplicaciones que se enfoque especialmente proveer contenido que pueda funcionar con condiciones de conexión en baja latencia.
3- Educar a las personas para insertase en la sociedad en un nuevo ámbito, ciencias de la computación, en una cultura que no require tener un titulo universitario.
4- Adopción de Javascript como lenguage de pila.

name: Tarus Balog
bio: Tarus Balog has been involved in managing communications networks professionally since 1988, and unprofessionally since 1978 when he got his first computer - a TRS-80 from Radio Shack. Having worked as a network management consultant for many years, he was constantly frustrated in the lack of flexibility involved in commercial solutions such as OpenView and Tivoli, as well as shocked by their high prices. Looking for a better solution, he turned to open source and joined the OpenNMS project in 2001 and become the principal administrator of the project in 2002. Since then he has managed not only to make a living working with free software, but the OpenNMS Group, the services company behind the project, has thrived. He is an outspoken evangelist for free and open source software and the communities it inspires.
title: So You Want to Start an Open Source Business?
abstract:
Love free software? Want to make money with free software? Are you crazy?

If you are, this talk is for you. This presentation will discuss how a business in open source software is different that a normal software company, and how you can be successful even if your software is free.
description:
Someone who is a good cook might often hear “You should open a restaurant!”. While that is definitely a compliment, there is a tremendous distance between the kitchen and a storefront. Likewise, people who love free and open source software often want to do it full time as a business, but how do you get started? Where do the customers come from? What do you sell? How do you pay the bills?

These questions and more will be discussed in “So, You Think You Want to Start an Open Source Business?”, a talk which will cover most of the steps from “idea” to “profit!”. It is aimed at anyone with an interest in doing open source full time or entrepreneurs who want to bring an idea to life.
notes:
I have given presentations at a number of open source conferences and I look forward to visiting Cuba in November. While I understand Spanish and can speak it at an elementary level, I'll will be bringing another member of the OpenNMS team, Alejandro, who is originally from Venezuela, so that we can better participate in all three days.

I blog about free and open source software here: https://www.adventuresinoss.com/

A video of a keynote I gave at the SCaLE conference can be found here: http://www.ustream.tv/recorded/4904528

My talk will be in English but we will be able to answer questions in either English or Spanish.

abstract:
Projections expect that by 2020 there will be 30 billion devices on the Internet, rising to 75 billion by 2025. How will they be monitored?

OpenNMS is a 100% free and open source monitoring platform designed to scale to the Internet of Things. Learn all of the great things about this project.
description:
OpenNMS is the most amazing piece of software you've never heard about, even though it has been around since 2000. It is a network monitoring platform designed to scale to the Internet of Things, and yet it is 100% free and open source software. It is used by some of the largest companies in the world.

This presentation covers What's Happening with OpenNMS. The project has grown considerably and this talk will cover the new technology such as NewTS (a new time series database built on Cassandra), the Minion (distributed monitoring) and OpenNMS Compass (mobile client).

There will be demonstrations of the new features as well as some funny stories about working with an open source project.

title: Building Engaging Virtual Reality Experiences for the Web
abstract: WebVR is incredibly exciting for its potential to democratize both the creation and consumption of VR content.  We'll start with a brief overview of the state of WebVR and UX best practices, then we'll dive in and show you how you can start developing VR projects with HTML and JS using A-Frame.
description:
A-Frame is a powerful and flexible open source framework that makes it surprisingly easy to get started developing VR experiences. It provides an accessible entry point for beginners and is endlessly extensible to suit the needs of advanced users. A-Frame is free and open source so it makes VR development available to the widest possible variety of people. Virtual Reality has the potential to make a tremendous impact on the way we interact with the world, so it's important that these technologies are built by and for all kinds of communities. This talk will instruct the audience in how to begin developing VR projects with HTML and Javascript and provide a foundational context for their new creations.

We'll start with a quick overview of the WebVR API, what it does and in which browsers. Then we'll take a look at some of the most recent research about what makes a safe, entertaining and useful VR experience. The last half of the talk will be a how-to on getting started with A-Frame, using the A-Frame Inspector and building components.

Attendees should leave confident in their ability to explore this exciting new domain using their existing web development skills.

title: Level Up Your React Form Prowess
abstract: Rare is the app that doesn’t rely on forms to obtain data from users, but how well do you really know them in React? If you’re just starting out in React, or if you’re more experienced in React but swimming in a sea of code complexity, come learn how you can improve your form prowess.
description:
In this session, we’ll learn what the options are when it comes to building forms, weighing their pros and cons and giving you the practical tools you need to become a React form ninja.

Have you only ever used controlled input forms? Why? We’ll explore both controlled and uncontrolled forms and answer the important question of when you should use one over the other, smashing a few myths along the way. How do we address the thorny issue of state management when building our forms? We’ll also explain concepts of encapsulation and how you would approach state both with and without Redux. Do you need validations? Check, we got that too.

You’ll get the most out of this session if you’re familiar with React components and ES6 syntax. You’ll get all the fancy concepts you need through code examples. And don’t worry if all of this didn’t make sense… it will.

title: JS WTF
abstract: This is simple. **I want to talk about the bad stuff on JavaScript and clarify it so we don't have to discuss it again.** Why? *(Now you sound a lot like my girlfriend)* So we can avoid it and be happy forever. Can we do this? I wish my girlfriend understood this too.
description:
All who have played with JavaScript have felt what R. Kelly believes to be [flying](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GIQn8pab8Vc).

Unfortunately, during these flights we can find some cold breezes that make us think "What the f*"*. Well, in JavaScript, these WTFs are just the way it is. Sometimes you're flying just nice, others you're crashing cold.

Let's fly for a minute:

`true + true === 2   // true`

`true - true === 0   // true`

`true === 1 // false`

I know the felling 💩

Fortunately, for all weird things there's always an explanation (except maybe for [this](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o1eHKf-dMwo)) and JavaScript is no exception.

In this talk we will see some of the JavaScript's weirdest things and try to understand how and why they happen.

The only requirement for this talk is to listen to [Never Gonna Give You Up](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dQw4w9WgXcQ) from Rick Astley. Some of these things are really mind blowing.
notes:
Unfortunately, some of the JavaScript's weird behaviour is actually developers' real struggle to try to understand why their code behaves the way it does. 

JavaScript is amazing but sometimes it can be trick. We can ignore the tricky parts and hope for the best, or choose to be the best by knowing how JavaScript works.

No advance knowledge is needed. Only a bit of craziness and fun. And, for course, some open mind. All these are the perfect combo for enjoying even more the magic that we do.

We should share our love for JavaScript even when that love comes from those things that we don’t love that much.

I’m passionate about teaching and sharing. I have been doing some share for [universities](https://www.facebook.com/blip.pt/photos/pcb.10153874029028818/10153874026213818/?type=3&theater), [at my company](https://goo.gl/photos/rdEtJPD1rnwVthh47) and on [some events](https://goo.gl/photos/SNCMPY3R8EFHCQhk6). 

Underneath that I have some crazy and fun with me. I’m a huge advocate of learning while smiling.

title: Pragmatic Angular: The only tutorial you've been missing
abstract:
Let's have a look at the state of the web platform:
- Which issues could be solved even simpler by using Angular
- What are the best practices on these
- How the code could look like for some real life examples
- ...And when Angular is not the best choice (do you remember "pragmatic" in the title?)
description:
Let me guess: as a web front-end developer you've read a lot of articles, blog posts, watched some sessions where they introduce the frameworks, or, on the contrary, go too deep into specific details, or even compare ones with others, sometimes in a very passionate way. I'm here with another approach.

Let's have a look at the state of the web platform and requirements for the applications we build. How can we fulfil the last ones using incredible power of modern browsers' possibilities. Only after having the problem/solution list ready, we will check:
- Which issues could be solved even simpler by using Angular
- What are the best practices on these
- How the code could look like for some real life examples
- ...And when Angular is not the best choice (do you remember "pragmatic" in the title?)

As a takeaway from this session, you will have a better overview of web platform new features, how to use them to build high-quality apps, and a rational decision on when (and - the most important - how) the Angular could work for you.
notes:

I held dozens of front-end sessions for local and international conferences, and I've found a way to build my talks the way they are useful for the attendees.

Again, no bias, only facts, both strong and weak sides.

I hope to gather all the web front-end developers, who wish to deepen knowledge of the web platform possibilities. The frameworks are just tools (there is no silver bullet), and choosing the proper one could make your developer experience better, and your customer happier. * Extend angular lazy component
* Register component
* Specify files
* Remove files from index.vm
* Specify module
* Specify component
* Add another entry to package.json
* Load manifest in index.vm
* Instantiate component
* Pass topology

title: The (crazy) state of modern web dev in 2017
abstract: Having to solve challenges arising from an ever more capable web platform and increased user expectations leads developers to jump on one hype train after the other, ignoring the downsides. I'll show how conventional and proven technologies can solve the same problems with less boilerplate work.
description:
As the Web Platform becomes ever more capable, web applications are increasingly ambitious and users adopt their expectations along the way. This leaves developers with numerous challenges to solve that were mostly unheard of even one or two year ago. While there is a plethora of solutions to these problems available and new ones are popping up each day, most of these are not yet based on well established patterns and conventions, leaving developers with having to connect the dots themselves. Doing so means teams spend a significant amount of their time not building the core product and generating business value but figuring out solutions to more fundamental challenges.

In this talk I'll show how conventional solutions backed by vivid communities as well as established, proven tools liberate teams from solving problems that should not actually be in their problem domain at all. Instead they can focus on iterating on their core product while still keeping up with the latest and greatest in web technology and meeting ever increasing user expectations. We will look at all levels of the stack and cover backend and frontend as well as the data transport layer between the two.
notes:
I'm actually working on a better title for this but haven't really settled on one yet. Currently I'm thinking about "The hypetrains are going nowhere - join me on the productivity train!" but it seems slightly too long.

I will use Ember.js, Elixir/Phoenix, PostgreSQL and JSON API (which is the stack we have lots of experience in) as examples for proven technologies and conventional solutions that liberate devs by imposing constraints on them.

I have worked with conventional frameworks both on the server as well as on the client side for the last 10 years and wouldn't want to go back to rolling my own solutions again - something I witness a log of developers doing in a false believe that it is somehow necessary to roll your own if you want to build a truly great web app. Many developers would totally ignore the downsides that rolling their own solutions have and won't see how the effect of doing so is often even negative in performance etc. I have also used many of the hyped NoSQL datastores and witnessed all the problems that come with them first hand. I often see teams making the same mistakes that I made and think it's time to rethink what the core of our jobs is which is to create business value and iterate on our core products instead of creating and maintaining our own customized solutions only to (perhaps) optimize everything to the max (which is often irrelevant or results in the opposite even).

title: The Duke Adventures: How we won the Java's Oscar by Increasing CS literacy in Guatemala
abstract: Guatemala Java User Group created the project "Dukes Adventures", by partnering with education institution, JUG members traveled through the country promoting computer science as a path for development with workshops and conference, winning the prestigious Duke's Choice Award due their efforts.
description:
Guatemala is one of the less developed countries in University attendance between Latin America, currently the government estimates that just only 2% of the university-age population has access to university education and only 7% of the original 2% obtain a university degree -i.e. 0.29% of the population -, being one of the countries with less students pursing degrees in science and technology.

However, it is widely known that you do not need a university degree to shine in the IT field if you work hard. As result, computer science is gaining momentum in Guatemala as a path to personal and economic development.

In GuateJUG we wanted to support this task and in 2015 to promote our annual conference "Java Day Guatemala" we started a journey through "forgotten" places in our country, creating the "Java Day Guatemala Tour" project, being renamed as "The Duke Adventures".

With the collaboration of local study centers -e.g Universities, high-schools and elementary schools- we started a trip to the four coordinates of the republic, combining two of our passions:

*  Traveling in our country
*  Java

By organizing bootcamps, conferences and workshops, GuateJUG members and volunteers shared their knowledge of Java technologies (and related) on any of its platforms, contributing to the development of the country by empowering people with IT tools in order to pursue careers, business and knowledge in computer science.

For us, the Duke adventures has been an opportunity to re-discover the country, make friends in each region, and generate a positive impact on people's lives, while generating a positive impact on us. Just needed, a laptop, a backpack and a good excuse :).

For the Java Community it meant a successful model for educational outreach, receiving as consequence the most prestigious prize in the Java world, the Duke's Choice Award 2016 (https://www.oracle.com/javaone/dukes-choice-award.html).

Currently Guatemala JUG is working in creating new communities and replicating the tour format, which will be described on the talk, as well as our experience on doing nation wide tours.

title: ​ Overcoming the Challenges of Mentoring
abstract: Successful mentoring doesn’t just happen, it’s planned. Let’s talk about what mentoring is, what it is not, and what makes for an effective mentorship.
description:
​There is an ongoing mantra within the developer community: that there are far more jobs available then programmers to fill them. Which should be an indication as to the wonderful potential for both business and those learning to code. Yet what often follows such statements are not words of joy but rather a list of frustrations related to the difficulty in finding and retaining enough skilled developers to fill these positions. 
The challenge is not in the number of newbies entering the field but the number who leave because they are not able to bridge the divide between bootcamps, online tutorials, books, videos, etc. to an employable developer who is able to contribute to the team. 
Kim has years of experience working with learners of various ages in helping them develop the skills they needed to be successful at whatever their chosen goal. She understands that for businesses to be successful, they must develop more effective and efficient ways of recruiting and retaining developers in order to meet organizational benchmarks. 
The developer community is a overwhelmingly generous one and a well designed mentoring or apprenticeship program could be one answer that business leaders and newbies are looking for.

- The business costs associated with corporate hiring managers inability to recruit and retain skilled workers to fill current and future entry-level positions are increasing (Queen, 2014). 
- 89 percent of organizational leaders stated that they are having difficulties filling open positions, which is causing them to either turn down orders, miss key deliverable deadlines or hire individuals from outside of the United States (Aho, 2015). 

Aho, K. (2015). The robotics industry: creating jobs, closing the skills gap. Techniques, (7), 22. Retrieved from https://www.acteonline.org/techniques/#.VpMcQq6rR0s

Queen, J. (2014). Hire power: to close the skills gap, states are teaming up with industries that need, but can't find, qualified workers. State Legislatures, (8), 16. Retrieved from http://www.ncsl.org/bookstore/state-legislatures-magazine.aspx

title: Make More Than Music with Tiny Computers, JavaScript and MIDI
abstract: We're living the halcyon days of tiny computers and JavaScript, but MIDI is a technology that's been around for much longer. In this talk we'll explore why it's implementation and prevalence in musical hardware makes for a uniquely intriguing and accessible platform for creative coding.
description:
Tiny computers such as the [RaspberryPi](https://www.raspberrypi.org), [Arduino](https://www.arduino.cc/) and [C.H.I.P.](https://getchip.com/) have finally reached a level of  performance and affordability that makes hardware experimentation accessible to everyone. At the same time, JavaScript has emerged as the lingua franca of web programming and can be found in many places beyond just the browser. 

What if I told you there was a mature protocol that's been around since 1983 and was uniquely poised to take advantage of this development?

Well, wonder no more and [meet MIDI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MIDI)! 

Sitting at convergence of these two things is MIDI — a niche protocol that's been around since 1983 and was originally designed for musical instruments to communicate with one another. It's event-oriented approach to messaging feels right at home in the asynchronous world of JavaScript & Node, and the prevalence of MIDI support in older musical equipment means you can find unique, hackable and affordable hardware at your local pawnshop or Craig's List.

This unlikely tech stack — Tiny Computers + JavaScript + MIDI — can lend itself to creative programming beyond music. George's Talk will explain how to get started, walk through several examples and elaborate on the future of this stack, not only as a platform for experimentation but for education as well.

bio: Nick is a senior software engineer at the [United States Digital Service](https://www.usds.gov/). Prior to that, he worked at Opower, Google, and Microsoft, and graduated from Cornell. title: The Most Good You Can Do as a Technologist
abstract: How can you use your tech powers for good? I've worked at Fortune 100 companies, double-bottom-line companies, and the United States Digital Service at the White House. By the end of the talk, you'll be ready to improve the world with your tech skills, with either a new job or a side project.
description:
A positive ethical impact makes a career much more fulfilling. Millennials disproportionately say they want their work to be mission-driven. And the current political climate has made people more interested in using their powers for good, across the political spectrum. Companies have gotten wise to this, and now almost everyone claims to be mission-driven, almost to the point of absurdity. I'll orient you to the landscape of possibilities.

This talk is inspired by Peter Singer's ["The Most Good You Can Do"](https://www.amazon.com/Most-Good-You-Can-Effective/dp/0300219865). Singer argues for what he calls "Effective Altruism", which is a rationality-based approach to having the greatest positive impact on the world. (This contrasts with what Singer identifies as "warm-glow giving", which is optimized to make the philanthropist feel good, but does not accomplish much else.) We'll discuss the ways that you can be an effective altruist in the tech world, with options for different levels of commitment and appetite for risk. And I'll share how you can avoid antipatterns, like vanity projects that look good but do not accomplish much.
notes:
I've spent a lot of time thinking about and working in this space, and I'm excited to share my insights. I want to help people distinguish projects that are real and impactful from those that just look good without producing results.

Here are my rough notes on what types of opportunities exist:

* Time intensive
    * Work for a mission-driven, change-oriented part of the government 
        * United States Federal Government
            * [USDS](usds.gov): be a consultant on high risk or critical government tech projects.
            * [18F](https://18f.gsa.gov/): build digital services for the American people.
            * [Presidential Innovation Fellows](https://presidentialinnovationfellows.gov/): bring modern tech practices to the government
            * [Office of Science and Technology Policy](https://www.whitehouse.gov/ostp): write better tech policies for the government
        * State and Local Government
            * [Austin Design, Technology, and Innovation Fellows](https://cityofaustin.github.io/innovation-fellows/)
        * Other Governments
            * [Government Digital Service (UK)](https://gds.blog.gov.uk/)
    * Work for a good contractor that works with the government. Easier lifestyle, but less autonomy for the type of impact you have.
        * [Ad-Hoc](https://adhocteam.us/)
        * [Nava](http://navahq.com/)
    * Work at a non-profit outside of government. Easier lifestyle, but potentially less leveraged impact.
        * [Code for America](https://www.codeforamerica.org/)
    * Work for a campaign or political organization. Impact levels depend on how much you agree with a particular political agenda.
        * [Hillary for America Tech Team](https://www.hillaryclinton.com/page/tech/)
        * [Civis Analytics](https://www.civisanalytics.com/)
        * [DNC](https://democrats.org/)
        * [RNC](https://www.gop.com/get-involved/jobs/)
    * Work at a B-corp
        * Tell the audience what the difference between a b-corp and non-profit is, and give examples of each
* Money intensive, low time committment
    * "Earning to Give": A method of altruism Singer identifies in which you just earn as much money as possible and then live frugally, donating as much as you can. Of course, it's possible to do this on a sliding scale.
* Not particularly time or money intensive
    * Work for a "double bottom line" company. Can feel pretty much like a normal tech job, but the impact is at risk of the senior leadership deciding they are more interested in the fiscal bottom line than the moral one.
    * Work at the social good part of a large company like Alphabet or Microsoft. You get the perks of a top-tier company, but you get to work on something that's fulfilling.
        * [Alphabet Debug Project](https://debugproject.com/)
        * [Microsoft Philanthropies](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/philanthropies/)
    * Find open source projects from groups like Code For America and contribute to them in your hobby time.

Each of those options have pros and cons based on what you're looking for. Then, once you know which category you want, you need to determine the efficacy of a given project. Important questions include:

* How measurable are the outcomes that the project can directly take credit for?
* How long does it take the project's impact to be measurable? Is this a multi-generational change, or something that will start making improvements immediately?
* Does the organization have an environment in which you can get work done?

title: Continuously Cooking: Our Path to Continuous Delivery
abstract: It's easy to continuously deliver a relatively simple app with low traffic, but the stakes get a lot higher when you have millions of users and four years of legacy code. We'll talk about how NYT Cooking has gone from shipping stale code every few weeks to shipping fresh code everyday.
description:
Four years ago, The New York Times launched NYT Cooking, a cooking-specific vertical showcasing 165 years of New York Times Recipes. That Rails Monolith is still in use today, delivering recipes, guides, and how-to videos to millions of users a month. 

After three years of legacy and working on a deprecated infrastructure, we were lucky if we shipped once every few weeks, and even then often led to deployment failures. Since then we've gone from shipping our monolith with very our fingers crossed to shipping every day with confidence. We'll look at how we changed our development practices, improved what and how we test, and automated our workflows. We'll also examine some of the unique enterprise concerns around continuous delivery and how we adapted and evolved our process so our engineering team works in tandem with design, and product to ship as often as possible.

Intended Audience: Developers, DevOps people who are working on complicated/large scale applications and haven't been able to recognize the benefits of continuous delivery. Audience members should walk away with some actionable takeaways about how they can ship faster, and how they can sell shipping faster to the rest of their organization.

description: El trabajo está encaminado en visualizar un contenido histórico patrimonial que existe en la Habana Vieja y está relacionado con el legado cultural de la esclavitud donde ademas la mujer tiene gran prescencia . title: Reciclaje de hardware con GNU/Linux
abstract: Uno de los problemas que generan el uso de PC es la acumulación de equipos en desuso por su obsolecencia. Las organizaciones no solucionan este problema y se ven obligados a retirarlos.  Aplicando los conceptos de reciclaje al hardware se pueden obtener soluciones sencillas a problemas cotidianos.
description:
Palabras claves: Reciclaje, Software libre, Hardware, GNU/Linux

Introducción:
Uno de los principales problemas que generan el uso de computadores es la acumulación de equipos en desuso por la falsa creencia de la obsolecencia de los mismos. En muchos casos las organizaciones no encuentran una solución efectiva a este problema y se ven obligados a donar o eliminar estos equipos.   

Si se aplica los conceptos de reciclaje al hardware se pueden obtener soluciones sencillas a problemas cotidianos. En esta presentación se describe como podemos recuperar equipos en desuso utilizando el sistema operativo GNU/Linux.

Reciclar hardware con Linux

Se puede decir que el núcleo del sistema es un medio importante para reciclar hardware principalmente porque esta diseñados para correr en equipos con procesadores o arquitecturas sencillas.

Un ejemplo claro se ve con la plataforma Intel x86, el kernel fue diseñado para un computador con un procesador 386, y esa misma filosofía se mantiene hasta el día de hoy. Es por ello que podemos ejecutar algún kernel moderno en un equipo con un procesador 486.

¿Por qué reciclar hardware?

Para aprender, el reciclaje de equipos viejos permite conocer arquitecturas antiguas y a la vez experimentar con servicios y configuraciones.
Para reutilizar recursos, de esta manera se puede ahorrar recursos financieros de la organización y no se acumularía hardware de desecho.
Para resolver un problema, no siempre es necesario invertir una cantidad de dinero para solucionar pequeños problemas si se tiene en cuenta que la organización posee hardware en desuso.

Algunas aplicaciones reales basadas en hardware reciclado:
- Router hecho en casa
- Servidor sencillo con pocos clientes
- Estaciones de trabajo
- Terminales de Sistema Distribuidos.

title: An Accessible Guide to Accessibility
abstract: ARIA? WCAG? JAWS? Web accessibility is often thought of as scary voodoo magic. But it doesn't have to be this way. With the right mindset, anyone can build accessible web content. Come learn how to make design, build, and test with disabled users in mind.
description:
Making your app accessible increases the size of your user base, often promotes search rankings, allows you to sell to the government, and is just the right thing to do. In this talk, we'll discuss:

* Starting with an accessible design, instead of trying to shoehorn accessibility in later
* Writing semantic HTML that can be understood by assistive technologies 
* Avoiding common design and implementation anti-patterns that hurt accessibility
* Understanding accessibility standards such as WCAG 2.0
* Ensuring that frameworks like Angular and React play nicely with accessibility
* Performing real-world testing that accurately assesses how a disabled user would interact with your app

You don't need to be a world-class developer to make accessible web content. With mindfulness and adherence to a few simple principles, you can broaden your user base and make the digital world a more inclusive place!
notes: # Why I want to give this talk I'm inspired to give this talk after my experience working with teams trying to make web content accessible in both the public and private sector. In the private sector, when I worked at Opower, people were initially afraid of client commitments that required making content accessible. Senior execs would even say "wow, you folks are really going to hate this." Then, I started working with the government, and I encountered an agency project where people were angry with each other and the product was not going to launch because of fear, uncertainty, and doubt around accessibility. After I solved the accessibility problems for the app, I had a lot more work left to do helping all the people involved think about accessibility in the right way. We launched on time, and now I want to save other teams from this unnecessary heartburn. Accessibility is an important topic. It helps app creators, by expanding their possible audience. And it helps disabled users, who deserve just as much access to content as anyone else. I see a lot of projects where accessibility is completely ignored because people think it's too hard. I'd like to give people the mindset and knowledge they need to get started building accessible content. Even if they just pick off the low-hanging fruit, it'll make the web a better place because there will be fewer sites that are completely unusable. # Details I've written two similar blog post drafts about this topic. One is now published on the [USDS Medium channel](https://medium.com/the-u-s-digital-service/mythbusters-guide-to-accessibility-92ccd88655c6#.i42s8d5oe). The other is copied below, and will not be published. If I give this talk at CubaConf, it'll have less of a government tilt. # An Accessible Guide to Accessibility: How We Approach Building for Everyone As modern technology improves, there's incredible opportunity to build services for people that stand to make a huge positive difference in their lives. But this will only be possible if the services and products we create are accessible to everyone. Too often, accessibility is seen as an intimidating topic, so it's neglected entirely, or it's slapped on to a product at the end. It doesn't have to be that way. This article aims to provide an introduction to accessibility that's approachable by all technologists, not just accessibility experts. In government, accessibility is defined by Section 508, enacted as an amendment to the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 to knock down barriers in information technology for the disabled. This article will talk specifically about Section 508, but as you'll see, general accessiblity and Section 508 compliance align perfectly. ## The Law Section 508 is not complicated. At its core, it says: > [I]ndividuals with disabilities ... have access to and use of information and data that is comparable to that provided to ... individuals with[out] disabilities. [*-Section 508 1194.1*](https://www.access-board.gov/guidelines-and-standards/communications-and-it/about-the-section-508-standards/section-508-standards#subpart_a) Translated into plain human-speak: > Everyone should be able to use government services, even if they have disabilities. ### WCAG The [Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG)](https://www.w3.org/WAI/intro/wcag) is a set of principles for designing accessible user experiences on the web. Section 508 lines up almost exactly with the recommendations found in WCAG 2.0, authored by industry experts, and backed by the [World Wide Web Consortium](https://www.w3.org/), which defines standards for the web. #### How to meet WCAG WCAG 2.0 is written as a set of technology-agnostic criteria, such as: > 1.4.1 Use of Color: Color is not used as the only visual means of conveying information, indicating an action, prompting a response, or distinguishing a visual element. > 2.4.2 Page Titled: Web pages have titles that describe topic or purpose. If all these statements apply to your web content, then it meets WCAG. Note that these statements are the "what," not the "how." WCAG makes no statements about implementation decisions – that's left to your discretion as the creator. And 508 itself says that the goal is a comparable experience for users with disabilities, not adherence to any particular suggestion that 508 contains for how to do that. WCAG provides a [set of techniques](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG20-TECHS/Overview.html), which are suggestions for how to meet the success criteria. For instance, [H51](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG20-TECHS/H51.html) provides methods for creating tables. When you're trying to meet 508, people may tell you that you **must** adhere to a specific WCAG technique. This is simply not true. For example, there are several tactics that are no longer applicable, advocate a deprecated approach, or create a bad outcome for users. You can use your discretion to decide what to follow and what makes sense for your service. ## Mindset Thinking about 508 the right way will make it easier to follow. Whether content is 508 conformant is largely a judgement call. The concrete requirements are minimal; the key goal of a "comparable" experience for disabled users is not an objective determination. There will always be improvements that can be made to the assisted user experience, just like there will always be improvements that can be made to the mobile or desktop experience. The fact that some aspect could be made better does not mean that content is not 508 conformant. Product owners needs to make a decision about how many resources shall be invested in UX. At a certain point, you have to say that the content is good enough and it's time to ship. ## US Web Design Standards The [US Web Design Standards](https://18f.gsa.gov/2015/09/28/web-design-standards/) provide guidance for accessibility out of the box. If you're working for the goverment, you can start with the US Web Design Standards and know that you're getting a good, accessible foundation. Additionally, each UI components offers guidance for how to ensure that it's accessible. ## Design Accessibility is easiest when you build it in from the beginning. Just like mobile has different design considerations than desktop, so does accessibility. Some designs are going to be onerous to make accessible after the fact. You can save a ton of development time and headaches by baking accessibility in upfront. Visually-impaired users interact with a UI in a fundamentally different way than sighted users. Sighted users can visually absorb the entire page at once, and quickly jump around to what appears to be the most relevant content. Non-sighted users perceive the page linearly, as a single stream of text served through a screenreader. Designers should consider both methods of interaction. **And to validate both these approaches, user testing should be done with both sighted and non-sighted users.** There are some aspects of design that are part of the UX for disabled users, but not for people without disabilities. For instance, tables can include optional explanatory text to help make it comprehensible for a non-sighted user. The design should specify whether this additional text is needed for a table, and if so, what that text is. In lieu of an affirmatively stated spec, developers and 508 testers are liable to make their own decisions and write their own user-facing text, which is likely to not be as thoughtfully-constructed as what the design team would produce. In other places, designers may wish to specify an alternate UX for non-sighted users. For instance, there may be a tooltip that contains additional explanation text when a user hovers over a word in a paragraph: ![popover image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/829827/18794219/726088d6-818c-11e6-8c1c-2c57c6f97e9c.png) This could be painful for someone using a screenreader, since it could be tricky to open and close the popover using the keyboard. Instead, the design could specify that for screenreaders, the popover should be hidden, and the text it contains should be in a parenthetical in the paragraph itself that's only visible for screenreaders. Some interactions are difficult when using a screenreader. Perhaps a design requires using non-standard keystrokes to operate an app. If these keystrokes conflict with the extra key commands that a screenreader introduces, then it may create confusion. For instance, JAWS users press `control+left arrow` to read the next piece of content. If a design calls for `control+left arrow` to make the app behave in a certain way, then making that behavior accessible to JAWS users requires overriding the JAWS keyboard commands, which can be very confusing. Instead, it's better to stick to standard keyboard operations, like pressing the enter key to submit a form. ## Implementation Achieving 508 compliance is much easier when you build accessibility support in from the beginning. Remediating content to add it is much more expensive. Here are some suggestions for how to build web content in an accessible way. If you write semantic, standards-conformant code, you'll get a lot of accessibility support out of the box. You can use [ARIA](https://www.w3.org/WAI/intro/aria) to provide additional support to screenreaders to communicate things that may be obvious visually but not just by inspecting the markup itself. title: Creación de un sistema de domótica de bajo costo con Raspberry Pi
abstract: En esta charla se hablará, a través de ejemplos prácticos, como se puede crear un sistema domótico extendible de manera sencilla con tecnologías libres y a bajo costo, se explicará el uso de telegram, programación de bots con lenguajes de alto nivel y electrónica basica todo desde Raspberri Pi
description:
Hasta hace poco más de una década el hecho de tener automatizada la gestión de una edificación que resultara accesible para la mayoría de las personas resultaba impensable, esto debido a los altos costos de implementación y mantenimiento, además de que era necesario equipos especializados para llevar esto a cabo y la programación de dichos equipos era muy compleja, ya que requieren conocimientos de programación en C o Ensamblador en algunos casos.
Con el pasar de los años el precio de los equipos de computación se han abaratado enormemente, además han salido proyectos de micro computadoras que llevan puertos de Entrada/Salida de Propósito General (GPIO por sus siglas en inglés) los cuales permiten controlar otros dispositivos externos a este de manera más sencilla pudiendo usar lenguajes de programación de alto nivel.
Uno de los dispositivos mas famosos en la actualidad ha sido el Raspberry Pi, Creado por  por una fundación caritativa en Reino Unido, con el fin inicial de crear una computadora que animara alos niños a aprender informática, pero rápidamente se hizo famoso en una gran comunidad de entusiastas, debido por un lado a su bajo costo y a su gran versatilidad, este es un microcomputador que posee, además de puertos GPIO, puertos USB y de red cableada, lo que lo convierte en uno de los mejores candidatos para crear dispositivos conectados con diferentes propósitos.
En esta presentación se mostrará como a través de diferentes tecnologías de hardware y Software Libre, puede construirse un sistema domótico que incluya el manejo remoto de diferentes aparatos de la casa o   vigilancia, entre otros temas, usando Raspberry Pi como núcleo del proyecto y el cliente de mensajería Telegram como el cliente de control.
notes:
Para la charla solo necesitaré conexión a internet y una mesa donde colocar los dispositivos que mostraré como ejemplo.
No se si soy la mejor persona para dar esta charla, pero dada mi experiencia en programación de bots y electrónica, como puede apreciarse en [mi blog](https://blog.willicab.com.ve) y [mi canal de youtube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCbBjUsWaxYI0QndSJGTdNZQ), considero que tengo la capacidad suficiente para hablar sobre el tema que he propuesto y en un lenguaje que personas con poco conocimiento del tema puedan entenderlo y comenzar a aplicarlo

abstract: This is the story of how focusing first on building a community of individuals who care about mentoring has allowed me to turn the idea of mentor matching for people learning to code into a multi-platform open source project.
description:
As someone new to the development community, finding your way around can be a daunting task. There are no defined paths, there's an overwhelming amount of information to ingest, and focus is an almost impossible task. Becoming an active member of open source projects is a great way for newbies to practice their coding skills, develop meaningful community relationships, and become a part of and add value to something bigger than themselves. You only have to look around you to see that individuals thrive when they feel that they have strong relationships and belong to a community.

1. Understanding the value of the Open Source Community as a newbie
2. Strategies for building community offline and online
3. Brining the community together to work on something that matters to them

title: Open Data For Emergency Response
abstract: This is a talk about finding open GIS data, and using open source tools to extend and manipulate the data to produce custom mobile maps that work offline.

title: How to make a dev advocate from every engineer inside the company
abstract:
Developer relations of a company is not the job of 1 person or a team. It's a responsibility of every engineer in a company. 
In this talk we will discuss how to promote the dev rel culture though out all developers. How to manage open source projects, encourage and facilitate meetups and more.
description:
## Issue
Developer relations for a IT company is not an easy way. It's a hard problem that solved in many different way, different heuristic approach.
At Wix, the company with over 500 engineers, we believe it's work not of 1 person or a team. It is a responsibility of everyone.
We all want to feed proud by the engineering part of a company where we work.
But how to achieve this? There's no silver bullet though.

## Solution
In this talk we will discuss different approaches that worked and not so much at tackling problems:
* open source projects
* speaking at meetups
* organizing workshops
* organizing conferences, and more

We will try to answer "simple" question: how to convert every engineer to a dev rel of your company.

name: Alicia V Carr
bio:
About Alicia Carr 
In 2012, while standing online at the Apple store waiting to buy my second generation iPad I met a 16-year-old young man. I asked him how did he get the money to buy an iPad and he told me he made a lot of money creating apps. Then I asked him how did he learn how to create an app. He said from youtube and That’s when I turn to my husband and told him “I want to do that.”
I started learning how to code in May 2012. On November 2, 2012 (will never forget the day) my husband told me to quit my job to follow my dream to become a iOS developer.
It took me 1½ years to learn Objective C. After books and online courses I went through, I started working on the Purple Pocketbook in January 2014 and finished the first version in March 2014. After a month of submitting the app to Apple, it finally got approved on May 2, 2014.
Purple Pocketbook is now Purple Evolution, Inc, (PEVO) the first domestic violence app for the state of Georgia which is now a national app.
Early 2014 I found and join the group called Women Who Code and I was so excited to be with other ladies wanting to connect and learn from each other that where coders as well. I then started the group within WWCODE called women iOS (WiOS) Developer Group.
I became such an active member of the group over two years working with WWCODE that Erica Stanley Founder/Director of WWCode Atlanta and Alaina Percival CEO/Founder WWCode felt I was an excellent fit for the Director of the Atlanta chapter.
And I love Women Who Code it like family.
Living my dream
I am 53 years old, been married for 35 years, have 3 children and 8 grandchildren. I love life, and I am experiencing my dreams as often and as soon as I can achieve them. My passion in life has been to be an entrepreneur and help others to see life differently with strength and passion.

title: Is it too late to learn how to program and how being a developer change my life
abstract: How I became a developer in my 50th. the challenges, the assumption and the victories and how women are not being recognized as an important part of the tech community.
description:
I will talk about how and why I wanted to be an iOS mobile developer at the age of 51. How a 16 year inspire me to learn to code and the challenges I face after becoming an iOS developer being the first self-taught African American woman mobile developer to create a domestic violence app dedicated to helping victims escape abuse and how Apple found me and was highlight at WWDC 2015 and 2016 keynote event.  Some people want to believe that people my age are out of touch with technology and as a woman, I have seen the best and the worst in the tech community but I know now that there is a solution at the end of the rainbow.

I will talk about how early adopters no longer look like the stereotypical hoodie-wearing gadget nerd obsessing over the specs of the latest iPhone—in part because they’re no longer men. Today young women are beating men to technology trends.

I also will talk about what people don't know is 70% of women are more active on our mobile device than men, women are more active with social media, shopping, photo apps, are more connected to entertainers and play more games on their smartphones. 

With that being said we the tech community need to open up our arm and embrace the change and think about how women in tech can change the way we see and create apps.
notes:
Alicia V. Carr is the first self-taught African American woman mobile developer to create a domestic violence app dedicated to helping victims escape abuse. She knew she had to utilize her acquired skills as a developer to make a difference.

Alicia decided to combine her new learned skills and long-time passion for domestic violence prevention to create Purple Evolution, Inc (PEVO) App. 

Early 2014 I join the group called Women Who Code and is now one of three Director of the Atlanta chapter.

Also, Apple has acknowledged me at the WWDC15 and 16 events.

abstract: An approach to teaching coding that does not create a false sense of competence.
description:
Long gone are the days when technology was just for the "nerds". Today, technology touches every industry and many parts of our personal lives and this trend will only continue to grow. Moving forward, those with the ability to understand the language of technology will be better positioned to take advantage of what lies ahead yet very few non-techies understand or even recognize the shifts that are taking place. As technology continues to move forward, the non-technical continue to fall further behind. In an effort to address this issue, I propose an introduction to technology process that will make becoming technically literate an option for the masses.

Details:
1. The importance of being code literate 
2. The challenges with current coding education platforms 
3. Let’s start with the basics

title: ¿Cómo conectar alumnos, maestros y escuelas con software libre?
abstract: Contaré acerca de mi experiencia capacitando a 600 docentes en el uso de tecnologías que los ayudaron a mejorar su forma de dar clase, su conexión con las familias de los estudiantes y con la comunidad escolar. description:
¿Cómo sería un sistema educativo en que los maestros pudieran saber de cada paso que sus alumnos están haciendo en su aprendizaje? ¿O uno en el que los padres y maestros pudieran estar en contacto todo el tiempo?; ¿o en el que directivos pudieran saber exactamente la situación en sus aulas? 
En esta charla me propongo contarles acerca de nuestra experiencia en Wingu capacitando a 600 docentes de un municipio en el uso de tecnologías gratuitas para escuelas. Estas capacitaciones no fueron solo acerca de cómo usar una herramienta particular, fueron fundamentalmente sobre cómo usar las herramientas que los docentes ya tenían de formas creativas para comunicarse mejor entre ellos y con la comunidad.
Algunos de los proyectos de los docentes que surgieron después de estas capacitaciones fueron una carpeta compartida entre docentes con planificaciones de clase, documentos compartidos entre padres y maestros para acordar sobre fechas de reuniones, correcciones en tiempo real de los trabajos de los estudiantes y muchísimas más cosas.
Además de esta experiencia, aprovecharé para presentar una herramienta gratuita y de código abierto para que los maestros tengan mejor feedback a lo largo de sus clases.
notes: Los únicos requerimientos técnicos son un cable HDMI y un proyector para mostrar la presentación. Si hubiera conexión a internet (aunque sea de muy baja velocidad) podría invitar a toda la gente de la audiencia a utilizar en tiempo real conmigo la herramienta que me gustaría presentar (esta herramienta está pensada especialmente para conexiones de internet de baja velocidad porque tienen que funcionar en escuelas con los dispositivos móviles que tengan los estudiantes).

abstract: A business perspective of how we went from a chaotic application focus on time to market to a scalable, tested and reliable solution using the React ecosystem and all the other stuff that they don't teach you on `todo` samples.

I will present a case in how after a few rounds of founding and getting more than 33 millions USD, we were forced to start from scratch and build an application which not only satisfy the market and the investors expectations but also make the ongoing day of front end developers more enjoyable using nothing more but the tools exposed by the React ecosystem and finally how a decision like this taken from early stages could also solve most of the issues that we deal with when work on legacy code according to the 20/80 rule also known as a Pareto distribution.
